extent.value: in 43 record cartons, 2 small flat boxes, and 1 manuscript box

abstract.value: Marvin Leiner is a scholar of Cuban education and the author of several books on educational reforms in the wake of the Cuban Revolution. The collection primarily consists of research Leiner conducted while living in Cuba during the 1968-1969 school year and during his many return visits in the 1970s and 1980s. Collection materials consist of reel-to-reel audio tapes, audiocassette tapes, slides, photographs, film reels, diaries, field notes, newspaper clippings, microfilm, floppy disks, transcripts of interviews, correspondence, and early manuscript drafts. A majority of the collection materials contain Leiner's research on Cuban education, sexual politics, and healthcare. A small portion of the collection contains Leiner's research regarding education in Nicaragua and China, as well his files for correpsondence, manuscript drafts, and speaking engagements. The Marvin Leiner Papers date from 1960 to 2004.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Marvin Leiner Papers; TAM 607; Box number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Marvin Leiner in 2012. The accession number associated with this gift is 2012.018

Leiner's best known book, <emph render="italic">Sexual Politics in Cuba: Machismo, Homosexuality, and AIDS</emph>, analyzes the Cuban practice of quarantining individuals with HIV in the context of the Cuban Revolution. The book also examines the social and educational effects of the Cuban government's intolerance of homosexuality and the efforts by Cuban educators to introduce sex education in schools. Leiner's research interests also include other education reforms in the wake of the Cuban Revolution, particularly the Escuela al Campo (School to the Countryside) program, which incorporated literacy, sports, and cultural programs into agricultural work in the countryside. His other works on the topic of education include <emph render="italic">Children Are the Revolution: Daycare in Cuba</emph> and <emph render="italic">Children of the Cities: Education of the Powerless</emph>, which he edited. Leiner is a Professor Emeritus of Education at Queens College, City University of New York.
The collection also contains files from Leiner's speaking engagements, early working manuscripts of his published works, and correspondence. These materials date from 1967 to 2004.

dsc.value:
Series I: Research Files27.5 Linear Feetin 26 record cartons, 2 flat boxes, and 1 manuscript legal box1961-2001Scope and Contents

Series I: Research Files contains Leiner's research materials on education, sexual politics, and health care in Cuba, Nicaragua, and China. A majority of the research files contain research created by Leiner during his trips to Cuba, including his diaries and field notes documenting his visits, photographs of school children and education professionals, and interviews with Cuban educators, psychologists, administrators, and other professionals. The research files also contain newspaper clippings, conference programs and notes, and scholarly publications Leiner gathered covering topics regarding Cuban education, health care, early childhood, gay rights, women's rights, and economic policies. A smaller portion of the research files contain Leiner's field notes and interviews from his trip to Nicaragua, and newspaper clippings and booklets regarding education and health care in Nicaragua and China.

Arrangement

Series I: Research Files has been organized into three subseries: Subseries I.A: Cuba; Subseries I.B: Nicaragua; Subseries I.C: China. The materials within Series I are physically arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

box1967-2004Scope and Contents

Series II: Writings and Correspondence contains Leiner's manuscript drafts for his published works, notes and drafts for his speaking engagements, and correspondence regarding grants, publications, and travel arrangements.

Arrangement

The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

Series III: Unprocessed Audiovisual and Born-Digital Media contains media created by Leiner during his research trips and while writing his manuscripts. Materials consist of audiocassette tapes, open reel audio tapes, open reel film, microfilm, floppy disks, slides, and photographs.

Arrangement

The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

Audiovisual and born-digital materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
